meeting_annotations.speaker: Tori Hoehler, NASA Ames
meeting_annotations.transcript: Amanda said, right, if if we could identify places whether it's IO now or or other environments that that people would generally agree even if we're permissive for other models of life, this is just not going to cut it, no way, right? I think that we would all agree, but we might give different answers as to why we think that's true. And then if you if you work backwards from that boundary and say how far how far back toward the middle can you come um and still agree that that, you know, everyone thinks that's uninhabitable for the following reasons and and at some point I I think we all would fall off that curve at different points for different reasons.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Aaron Engelhart - U of MN

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton, Georgia Institute of Technology (she/her/hers)

meeting_annotations.speaker: Aaron Engelhart - U of MN

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, and it it the paper that came a couple came to mind when we were talking about this. He had a paper last year. I just pasted in the chat. I'll put it on the slack so we have it for later where um he found a fungus that would grow in just ridiculously high perchlorate. It was like two and a half molar, which, you know, is is not quite one of these, you know, transient brines or things like that. But I think that just shows that at uh some of this stuff we can push it further than we think and we're kind of talking about two different ideas here whether it's you know, the the surface of IO sure maybe not, but at um yeah the, you know, these hypersaline environments. Um, I don't really want to go down the route of of the advanced astrobiology is just a a comment to provoke a little bit of thought. Um, but but I think that at least everything I'm hearing at the moment is assuming that we're talking about endogenically derived uh microbial organisms, the simplest possible uh for forms of life or or or their uh very basic uh descendants.
